metadata.title: High performance asymmetric supercapacitor based on polypyrrole/graphene composite and its derived nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jpowsour
High performance asymmetric supercapacitor based on polypyrrole/ graphene composite and its derived nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets
Jianbo Zhu a, b, *, 1, Tianyu Feng c, 1, Xianfeng Du c, **, JingpingWang d, Jun Hu a, LiPing Wei a
a School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710069, PR China b Institute of Analytical Science, Shaanxi Provincial Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Northwest University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710069, PR China c Electronic Materials Research Laboratory, Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education & International Center for Dielectric Research, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710049, PR China d College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi University of Science and Technology, Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710021, PR China
h i g h l i g h t s
Nano-sheet structural Polypyrrole and derived N-doped carbon. Asymmetric supercapacitors with high operational voltage. Capacity matching and mass loading of negative and positive electrodes.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 December 2016 Received in revised form 9 February 2017 Accepted 10 February 2017
Keywords: Polypyrrole Nitrogen-doped carbon Asymmetric supercapacitor High voltage
* Corresponding author. School of Chemical Engine Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710069, PR China. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: jianzhu@nwu.edu.cn (J. Zhu), (X. Du).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2017.02.034 0378-7753/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Neutral aqueous medium is a promising electrolyte for supercapacitors because it is low-cost, environmental-friendly and can achieve rapid charging/discharging with high power density. However, the energy density of such supercapacitor is significantly limited by its narrow operational voltage window. Herein, we demonstrated an effective approach to broaden the operational voltage window by fabricating an asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC) with polypyrrole/reduced graphene oxide (PPy/rGO) composite and its derived Nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets (NCs) as positive and negative electrode material, respectively. The homogeneous nano-sheet and mesoporous structure of PPy/rGO and NCs can facilitate rapid charge/ion migration and provide more active sites for ions adsorption/exchange to improve their electrochemical performance. Benefiting from high capacitance and good rate performance of PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes, the as-fabricated ASCs devices in a polyvinyl alcohol/LiCl gel electrolyte can realize a wide operational voltage of 1.6 V and deliver high energy density of 15.8 wh kg 1 (1.01 mWh cm 3) at 0.14 kW kg 1 (19.3 mW cm 3), which still remains 9.5 wh kg 1as power density increases to 6.56 kW kg 1, as well as excellent long-term cycling stability with about 88.7% capacitance retention after 10000 cycles. The remarkable performances suggest that the ASCs devices are promising for future energy storage applications.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Development of high-energy and high-efficient energy storage
ering, Northwest University,
xianfengdu@mail.xjtu.edu.cn
devices with short charging time and long lifetime has attracted tremendous attention due to the increasing concerns for environment and the increasing demands of portable energy consumption [1e3]. Supercapacitors (SCs), also known as ultracapacitors or electrochemical capacitors, are considered to be one of the most promising devices because of their high power density, fast dynamic response (charging-discharging at a very high rate) and long cycling life [4,5]. Unfortunately, the energy density of commercially available SCs is rather unsatisfying, at least one order of magnitude lower than that of conventional batteries [6]. Hence, to meet the
growing energy demands for electrical vehicles and next generation electronic devices, the energy density of SCs must be boosted further. The energy released by a supercapacitor can be expressed by the following equation:
E ¼ 1 2 CU2 (1)
where C is capacitance and U is the operational voltage window. According to this equation, the energy enhancement of SCs may be achieved by two approaches: capacitance enhancement or operational voltage window broadening. Based on charge storage mechanism, two types of capacitance are electrochemical double layer capacitance and pseudo-capacitance [3,7]. The former is based on two oppositely charged layers at the electrode/electrolyte interface separated by an atomic distance, and the pseudocapacitance is attributed to the fast and reversible redox reaction at electrode materials surface. According to the latest literature [8e11], nano-structured electrode materials can provide high surface area, easy electrolyte infiltration and low diffusion paths of electrolyte ions, which can improve the electrochemical double layer capacitance [4,9]. Some conducting polymers [12e15] and transition metal oxides [8,16e19] can provide large capacitance through the additional charge originating from pseudocapacitive behavior, even one order of magnitude larger than electrochemical double layer capacitance. Therefore, designing and preparing new nanostructured pseudocapacitive materials with high surface area and open diffusion path for the electrolyte ions can substantially increase the capacitance of electrodes.
On the other hand, with the viewpoint of broadening the operational voltage, to select an ionic liquid or organic electrolyte based on propylene carbonate (or acetonitrile), which can keep stable in awide operational voltagewindow (even up to 3.7 V), is an effective way to improve the energy density of supercapacitors [1,20]. Another way to broaden the operational voltage is to assemble asymmetric supercapacitors (ASCs), especially in an aqueous electrolyte. Compared with organic electrolytes, aqueous electrolytes can achieve high power capability and rapid charging/ discharging (in seconds) because of its high ionic conductivity and low viscosity [1,21], while its energy density is greatly limited by the low operational voltage, usually no more than 1.0 V. Therefore, the energy density of ASCs in aqueous electrolytes can greatly increase with the operational voltage, as well as its power rate capability can be maintained [22e25]. Recently, many efforts have been paid on these ASCs and some successful ways have been proposed to extend the operational voltage window and improve energy density [26e32]. In general, such ASCs are fabricated by using pseudocapacitance materials as the positive electrode with a carbon based materials (or another pseudocapacitance material) as the negative electrode (Table 1). For fabricating ASCs, the critical issue is to select high performance positive pseudocapacitance material and pairing with suitable negative material in order to obtain wide operational voltage window and high energy density with good rate capability and cycling stability.
According to the above considerations, in the work, we fabricated new ASCs containing nano-sheet polypyrrole/reduced graphene oxide (PPy/rGO) and its derived nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets (NCs) as the positive and negative electrode material, respectively, with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)/LiCl gel as the electrolyte. The electrochemical performances of PPy/rGO and NCs have been investigated by a three-electrode system in a 3 M LiCl electrolyte. Further, the matching of potential voltage window and mass loading of the positive and negative electrode has been optimized. These optimized ASCs devices could obtain a wide operational voltage of 1.6 V and realize high energy density of 15.8 wh kg 1
(1.01 mWh cm 3) at 0.14 kW kg 1 (19.3 mW cm 3), as well as excellent long-term cycling stability with about 88.7% capacitance retention after 10000 cycles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of electrode materials
sections.text: Pyrrole (Capchem, 99.8%) was distilled prior to use and stored at 10 C in a nitrogen atmosphere. All other reagents were commercially available with analytical grade from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and used as received without further purification. In a typical synthesis as reported in our previous literature [33], 100 ml of 1 g L 1 rGO and 0.1 M p-toluenesulfonate acid (TOSH) aqueous solution with 10 mmol (0.677 g) pyrrole monomer and was vigorously stirring at low temperature (below 4 C) for 30 min. Subsequently, 10 ml 0.1 M TOSH solution of 3 g ammonium persulfate (APS) was slowly added into the mixture. After further stirring for 24 h, the product PPy/rGO was separated by filtration, washed with ethanol and water to remove excess reactants, and dried at 60 C overnight under vacuum. To prepare the nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets (NCs), the PPy/rGO was annealed and carbonized at 900 C for 1 h under N2 atmosphere. The obtained NCs were thoroughly washed with HCl (0.1 mol L 1) to remove any inorganic salts, and thenwashed with distilled water until neutral pH and finally dried in an oven (120 C). The scheme of synthetic process is illustrated in Fig. 1a.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials characterization
sections.text: Microscopic investigation of the precursor PPy/rGO and NCswas carried out by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, S-4800) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM2100, JEOL) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The chemical structure of the products was ascertained by Raman spectroscopy (HORIBA Jobin Yvon) with a 514 nm laser light and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurement with an AXIS-ULTRA DLD (Al Ka X-ray source, 1486.60 eV). All binding energies of XPS measurement were referenced to the C 1s neutral carbon peak setting at 284.6 eV to compensate for surface charging effects. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the products were collected using an X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical, X'Pert PRO X) with Cu-Ka radiation (l¼ 0.15406 nm) by step scanning of 10 perminute. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms weremeasured at 77 K with a BECKMAN COULTERAUT SA3100 and the specific surface area were determined via the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method.

sections.heading: 2.3. Fabrication of supercapacitors and electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
Electrodes preparation: the slurry of 80% PPy/rGO (or NCs) sample, 10% carbon black (Super-P) and 10% PVDF (binder) in Nmethylpyrrolidone was coated on titanium foil and dried at 110 C overnight after dried at 50 C for 4 h.
Fabrication of asymmetric supercapacitors: the ASCs were fabricated by using PPy/rGO and NCs as positive and negative electrodes, respectively, with a filter paper as the separator and PVA/LiCl gel as the electrolyte. The PVA/LiCl gel was applied onto the electrodes and dry at room temperature to become quasi-solid state. This ASC was named as PPy/rGO//NCs. The PVA/LiCl gel was prepared according to the report in previous literature [34]. For comparison, symmetric supercapacitors based on PPy/rGO (or NCs) electrodes were fabricated in the same way, marked as PPy/rGO//PPy/rGO (or NCs//NCs).
Table 1 Specific surface area (SSA) and electrochemical performance of selected asymmetric supercapacitor and its electrode materials.

Fig. 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation of PPy/rGO and NCs, (bec) SEM images and (d) TEM image of PPy/rGO; (eef) SEM images and (g) TEM image of NCs.
Electrochemical measurements: all of the electrochemical performances were performed on the Versatile Multichannel Potentiostat 2/Z (VMP2, Princeton applied research). The electrochemical studies of individual PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes were performed in 3 M LiCl aqueous solution by a three-electrode system, in which platinum electrode and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used as counter and reference electrode, respectively.
Specific capacitance of each electrode and the supercapacitor devices can be calculated from the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves according to the following equations (2) and (3), respectively.
Cm ¼ 1 vmðU2 U1Þ

where Cm (F g 1) is the mass specific capacitance, m (g) is the mass of activematerials, v (V s 1) is the scan rate of CV curves, and U2eU1 (V) represents the potential window.

where Cm (F g 1) is the mass specific capacitance, I (A) is the discharge current, Dt (s) is the discharge time, m (g) is the mass of active materials, and DU (V) is the discharge voltage excluding the IR drop.
Moreover, energy density and power density of the supercapacitor devices were calculated using equations (4) and (5):

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The morphology of PPy/rGO and its derived NCs were characterized by SEM and TEM as shown in Fig. 1. Typical nano-sheet morphology can be seen for both PPy/rGO and NCs. Due to the framework supporting of rGO, PPy/rGO formed homogeneous sheet structure during the chemical polymerization process (Fig. 1b and c). Such structure of PPy/rGO can facilitate the electrolyte infiltration and provide accessible transmission channels and active sites for ion adsorption/exchange, which is beneficial to its application as electrode materials. For NCs, derived from PPy/rGO by carbonizing at 900 C, they retain the original nano-sheet structure of the PPy/rGO precursor after carbonization (Fig.1d). Nevertheless, the sheet size of NCs becomes thinner because of the burn-off and shrinkage of the previous (Fig. 1e). Moreover, by comparing the TEM micrograph of PPy/rGO and its derived NCs (Fig. 1d, g), it can be found that the fragment of NCs is thinner and more stretchable than that of the PPy/rGO precursor.
The BET surface area and pore-size distribution of PPy/rGO and NCs were investigated by the nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements and presented in Fig. 2. The isotherms can be classified as a type IV isotherm (in the Brunauer classification) with hysteresis loops observed at relative pressures P/P0 of ca. 0.45 to 1.0, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure [35]. The BET surface area of PPy/rGO and NCs is 124 and 383m2 g 1, respectively. Comparing with recent literature report about the BET surface area of PPy (usually only 20e60m2 g 1) [32,36], this PPy/rGO composite has higher specific surface area. It can be attributed to the addition of rGO which can reduce the agglomeration of PPy and form uniform nano-sheet structure during the polymerization process. On the other hand, the thinner and more stretchable morphology of NCs introduced larger specific surface area, which can providemore accessible active sites for ion adsorption corresponding to a large electric double-layer capacitance. The obvious hysteresis loop can be found in the adsorption/desorption isotherm of NCs, suggesting that NCs have more mesoporous. Moreover, the mesoporous size and its distribution are obtained by the Barrett-Johner-Halendar method on the basis of the adsorption isotherm. Pore size distributions of PPy/rGO and NCs have a narrow mesoporous size distribution in the range of 2.0e5.0 nm, while the mesoporous volume of NCs is larger than that of PPy/rGO. It is generally accepted that the surface area and porosity of the electrode materials are directly correlated to the specific capacitance. High surface area can provide more active sites for ion electrostatic adsorption to increase electrochemical double layer capacitance. Meanwhile, the mesoporous
structure can improve the electrolyte infiltration and ions exchange, and facilitate the dynamic charge propagation [4,37].
The FT-IR spectra of PPy/rGO and its derived NCs are shown in Fig. 3a. In the FT-IR spectra of PPy/rGO, the absorption peaks at 1540 and 1462 cm 1 are assigned to the anti-symmetric and symmetric ring-stretching modes, which are the characteristic peaks of PPy chains [27,38]. The peak near 1297 cm 1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of CeN, and the peak at 1174 cm 1 are induced by absorption of CeC and CeN stretching vibrations between two pyrrole rings. Peaks at 1041, 895 and 3492 cm 1 are attributed to NeH in plane deformation vibrations, the bending vibration of¼ CeH, and the stretching vibrations residual hydroxyl from rGO, respectively [38,39]. For NCs, the absorption peaks at 720, 1384, 1628, and 3436 cm 1 can be attributed to NeH out of-plane bending vibrations, CeN stretching vibrations, C]N stretching vibrations, and OeH (or NeH) stretching vibrations, respectively [40]. It can be seen that the absorption peaks of CeN and C]N became more significant, which can be attributed to that nitrogen atom doped in carbon network will induce strong IR activity due to a net dipole moment. In addition, as shown in Fig. 3b, the XRD pattern of PPy/rGO with a broad diffraction peak located at 18e30 , which indicated that it is mainly amorphous structure. For NCs, two diffraction peaks at 2q values of around 26 and 43 can be assigned to (002) planes of hexagonal carbon material (JCPDS, Card No. 75- 1621) [41], indicating that an amorphous carbonwas obtained after carbonization.
In order to investigate the elemental composition and bonding configurations, XPS was performed on the PPy/rGO and NCs samples. The spectra show strong signals of carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and oxygen (O) elements for both PPy/rGO and NCs (Fig. 3c). For PPy/ rGO, the presence of doping ions (TOS ) introduced a signal of sulfur element. And the chemical state of the nitrogen species on the surface of the PPy/rGO and NCswas further studied by the highresolution N 1s region XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 3d and e, the spectrum of PPy/rGO was deconvoluted into two peaks of 399.8 eV and 401.2 eV, which were associated with benzenoid amine (eNHe) and protonated benzenoid amine (-NþH-) within the pentagonal PPy ring, respectively [42]. The content of eNþHdepended on the doped degree, which can improve the electronic conductivity of PPy based materials. A high doped degree of 33.8% could be calculated for the PPy/rGO sample by determining the contribution of positively charged nitrogen (-NþH-) to the total nitrogen content. On the other hand, for NCs, the N 1s region XPS spectrum could be fitted by three peaks located at 398.2 ± 0.2 eV,
399.7 ± 0.2 eV and 400.8 ± 0.2eV, revealing the presence of three different environments of N elements: pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic/ pyridine N (N-5) and quaternary N (N-Q), respectively [40,41], as illustrated in Fig. 3f. A nitrogen level of 3.9 at% was calculated from XPS analysis, in which, the percentages of N-6, N-5 and N-Q are 14.6%, 8.2%, and 77.2%, respectively. According to previous literature [37,43e45], the introduction of doped N atoms could improve the electrical conductivity to enhance ion/charge transport and adsorption, and the presence of N-6 and N-5 could provide additional capacitance through introducing the pseudocapacitive behavior, especially in acidic aqueous electrolytes.
Electrochemical performances of PPy/rGO and NCs as electrode materials for supercapacitors were estimated by a three-electrode system in 3 M LiCl aqueous solution. Fig. 4a and b shows the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the PPy/rGO positive electrodewith a potential window of 0e0.6 V (vs. SCE) and NCs negative electrode with a potential window of 1.0 to 0 V (vs. SCE) at various scan rates, respectively. As the scan rate increasing from 10 to 100 mV s 1, the CV curves in their respective working potential window with nearly rectangular shape indicate good capacitive behavior for both PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes. Fig. 4c shows the specific capacitances of the PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes at different scan rates according to equation (1). A highest specific capacitance of 310.3 F g 1 for PPy/rGO can be obtained at a scan rate of 10 mV s 1 with good retention of 57.7% of the initial capacitance as the scan rate increases from 10 to 500 mV s 1, while the highest specific capacitance obtained for NCs is 196.5 F g 1 (10 mV s 1) with retention of 61.1% as the scan rate increases to 500 mV s 1. Fig. 4d shows the CV curves of both PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes at a scan rate of 10 mV s 1. The two quasi-rectangular shaped curves occupy a potential window from 1.0e0.6 V (vs. SCE), suggesting an asymmetric supercapacitor fabricated from these two electrodes could have a high operational voltage window of 1.6 V. Moreover, the galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves of these two electrodes show a typical triangular curve with two approximate
linear lines (Fig. 4e). The positive potential for PPy/rGO can reach 0.6 V (vs. SCE), while the negative potential for NCs can reach 1.0 V (vs. SCE), implying the operational voltage of the ASCs based on these two electrodes can be raised to 1.6 V.
For an asymmetric supercapacitor, charge storage on the positive and negative electrodes will follow the relationship of qþ ¼ q-. To balance the charge storage, the mass matching of the positive and negative electrodes was optimized by the following equation:
mþ m ¼ Cm U Cmþ Uþ (6)
where m (g) is the mass of the active material, Cm (F g 1) is the specific capacitance, and U (V) is the voltage range for the positive (þ) and negative ( ) electrodes, respectively. Fig. 4f shows themass ratios (mþ/m-) of the active materials of two electrodes (PPy/ rGO:NCs) calculated by equation (6). The value of mþ/m- was about 1.1 at various scan rates and it had a slight increase from 1.05 to 1.12 as the scan rate increases from 10 to 500 mV s 1. The reason could be attributed to the specific capacitance of positive electrode (PPy/ rGO) decayed more obvious than that of negative electrode (NCs), especially at high scan rates. According to the above analysis, in this work, we had assembled the ASCs with an optimized mass ratio (mþ/m-) of 1.1.
The ASCs devices were fabricated by using PPy/rGO as positive electrode and NCs as negative electrode with PVA/LiCl gel as the electrolyte. Fig. 5a exhibits the CV curves (at 10 mV s 1) of the asfabricated ASCs measured at different voltage regions (from 0-1.0 V to 0e1.6 V). The rectangular-like curves indicated that these ASCs can be cycled reversibly in a wide voltage window of 1.6 V. Moreover, the CV curves of the as-fabricated ASCs at various scan rates from 20 to 500 mV s 1 show quasi-rectangular shapes (Fig. 5b), implying good capacitive behavior and excellent fast chargedischarge performance. The specific capacitance of these ASCs calculated from the CV curves was 43.2 F g 1 (based on the mass of
active materials on both positive and negative electrodes) at a scan rate of 20mV s 1 and retained 29.7 F g 1 at 500mV s 1, indicating a good rate performance (Fig. 5c). On the other hand, the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves of the as-fabricated ASCs at different current densities (Fig. 5d) show typical symmetric triangular shapes, suggesting a good fast charge-discharge performance, which is consistent with the results of CV profiles. Meanwhile, the rate capability and cycling stability of the as-fabricated ASCs were performed at various current densities from 2 to 32 mA cm 2 and return to 2 mA cm 2. As shown in Fig. 5e, the initial specific capacitances were 47.5, 46.8, 44.3, 41.8, and 39.6 F g 1 at various current densities of 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 mA cm 2, and high capacitance retention ratios of 95.3%, 97.5%, 98.4%, 99.1% and 99.3% could be obtained after each 1000 cycles, respectively. As the current density return to 2 mA cm 2 after 5000 cycles, the specific capacitance still retained 46.9 F g 1, implying excellent cycling stability. Additionally, the long-term cycling performance of as-fabricated ASCs at 10 mA cm 2 is shown in Fig. 5f. Capacitance retention of 95.8% of the initial capacitance had been observed after 5000 cycles implying good long-term cycling stability of the ASCs. The visible capacitance decay after 10000 cycles (about 11.3%) may be due to that both PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes have capacitance decay during the long-cycling stability test, as well as the asynchronized decay of PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes will further aggravated capacitance decay of the ASCs, especially during the latter 5000 cycles.
Energy density and power density are two important parameters widely used to evaluate the performance of an energy storage device. To completely evaluate the electrochemical performance of the as-fabricated ASCs, energy density and power density of these ASCs were estimated from the GCD test according to equations (4) and (5). Fig. 6a compares the gravimetric energy and power densities of the as-fabricated ACSs to that of PPy/rGO (or NCs) based symmetric supercapacitors. The as-fabricated ACSs is able to possess a maximum energy density of 15.8 wh kg 1 (0.14 kW kg 1),
which is about 2.5 times of that of NCs based symmetric supercapacitors and 3 times of that of PPy/rGO base symmetric supercapacitors. Notably, as power density increases to 6.56 kW kg 1, the energy density still remains 9.5 wh kg 1, again suggesting its excellent rate performance. Moreover, the effect of mass loadings on the capacitance and specific energy/power performance was further investigated by fabricating ACSs with threemass loadings of the positive and negative electrodes (2.2 mg: 2 mg, 4.4 mg: 4 mg, and 6.6mg: 6mg, respectively). As shown in Fig. 6b, the gravimetric specific capacitance generally decreased with increasing mass loading of the electrodes. The areal specific capacitance increased with increasing mass loading, while the increase rate gradually decreased. And then, the volumetric power and energy densities of the as-fabricated ACSs with various mass loading are shown in Fig. 6c. The ACSs of low mass loading was able to own a maximum energy density of 1.01 mWh cm 3 at 1 mA cm 2, and it could remain 0.73 mWh cm 3 at 40 mA cm 2. With the mass loading increasing, the volumetric energy densities at the current densities lower than 40mA cm 2 had an obvious increase reflecting good ion transport of themesoporous electrodematerials, while the increase is unnoticeable at high current densities. The reasonwas attributed to large mass loading would increase the transmission path of charges and electrolyte ions, which led to low utilization of the active materials at high current densities.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, nano-sheet PPy/rGO and its derived nitrogendoped carbon nano-sheets (NCs) with superior capacitive performance have been developed and demonstrated as the positive and negative electrodes for a new ASC device with PVA/LiCl gel as the electrolyte. Due to the high capacitance and good rate performance of PPy/rGO at positive potential window of 0e0.6 V (vs. SCE), and that of NCs at negative potential window of 1.0 V to 0 (vs. SCE), this device could stably operate with a wide voltage
window of 1.6 V, exhibiting good rate performance, high energy density of 15.8 wh kg 1 (1.01 mWh cm 3), and excellent longterm cycling stability (95.8% capacitance retention after 5000 cycles and 88.7% retention after 10000 cycles). It is thus expected that such ASCs hold great promise for the low-cost energy storage applications.

referenceMentions.context: Supercapacitors (SCs), also known as ultracapacitors or electrochemical capacitors, are considered to be one of the most promising devices because of their high power density, fast dynamic response (charging-discharging at a very high rate) and long cycling life [4,5].

Supercapacitors (SCs), also known as ultracapacitors or electrochemical capacitors, are considered to be one of the most promising devices because of their high power density, fast dynamic response (charging-discharging at a very high rate) and long cycling life [4,5].
Unfortunately, the energy density of commercially available SCs is rather unsatisfying, at least one order of magnitude lower than that of conventional batteries [6].

According to the latest literature [8e11], nano-structured electrode materials can provide high surface area, easy electrolyte infiltration and low diffusion paths of electrolyte ions, which can improve the electrochemical double layer capacitance [4,9].

metadata.abstractText: Neutral aqueous medium is a promising electrolyte for supercapacitors because it is low-cost, environmental-friendly and can achieve rapid charging/discharging with high power density. However, the energy density of such supercapacitor is significantly limited by its narrow operational voltage window. Herein, we demonstrated an effective approach to broaden the operational voltage window by fabricating an asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC) with polypyrrole/reduced graphene oxide (PPy/rGO) composite and its derived Nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets (NCs) as positive and negative electrode material, respectively. The homogeneous nano-sheet and mesoporous structure of PPy/rGO and NCs can facilitate rapid charge/ion migration and provide more active sites for ions adsorption/exchange to improve their electrochemical performance. Benefiting from high capacitance and good rate performance of PPy/rGO and NCs electrodes, the as-fabricated ASCs devices in a polyvinyl alcohol/LiCl gel electrolyte can realize a wide operational voltage of 1.6 V and deliver high energy density of 15.8 wh kg 1 (1.01 mWh cm 3) at 0.14 kW kg 1 (19.3 mW cm 3), which still remains 9.5 wh kg 1as power density increases to 6.56 kW kg 1, as well as excellent long-term cycling stability with about 88.7% capacitance retention after 10000 cycles. The remarkable performances suggest that the ASCs devices are promising for future energy storage applications. © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
